explanations.summary: During bladder FILLING: sympathetic dominates (beta-2 relaxes detrusor, alpha-1 contracts internal sphincter), pressure stays LOW despite volume increase (compliance), sphincters remain CLOSED.

whyCorrect.a: During filling, SYMPATHETIC tone dominates: beta-2 receptors relax detrusor muscle, alpha-1 receptors contract internal urethral sphincter. This promotes urine storage.

whyIncorrect.b: Pressure does NOT increase proportionally with volume during filling. The bladder has high COMPLIANCE - volume increases with minimal pressure rise until near capacity.
whyIncorrect.c: Internal sphincter is CONTRACTED (not relaxed) during filling to prevent leakage.
whyIncorrect.d: External sphincter is also CONTRACTED during filling (somatic/voluntary control maintains continence).

explanations.summary: Bladder function: (1) Abdominal muscles CAN assist emptying (Valsalva); (2) NO water reabsorption through urothelium; (3) Parasympathetic causes CONTRACTION not relaxation; (4) No Bayliss effect in bladder; (5) Healthy adults have complete emptying.

whyCorrect.a: Abdominal muscle contraction (Valsalva maneuver) increases intra-abdominal pressure, which can assist bladder emptying by compressing the bladder.

whyIncorrect.b: Urothelium is impermeable to water - NO reabsorption occurs. Vasopressin acts on collecting ducts, not bladder.
whyIncorrect.c: Parasympathetic activation causes detrusor CONTRACTION for emptying, NOT relaxation during filling.
whyIncorrect.d: Bayliss effect (myogenic response) applies to blood vessels, not bladder. Bladder compliance is different.
whyIncorrect.e: Healthy adults have COMPLETE bladder emptying. Residual urine indicates dysfunction.

explanations.summary: Bladder autonomic innervation: Parasympathetic uses MUSCARINIC receptors (M3) on detrusor. Sympathetic uses BETA-2 (detrusor relaxation) and ALPHA-1 (sphincter contraction). Sympathetic inhibits parasympathetic presynaptically. NOT nicotinic on bladder.

whyCorrect.b: Sympathetic beta-2 receptors on detrusor muscle cause RELAXATION during filling phase.
whyCorrect.c: Sympathetic fibers exert PRESYNAPTIC INHIBITION on parasympathetic terminals, reducing ACh release during storage phase.
whyCorrect.e: Parasympathetic activates MUSCARINIC (M3) receptors on detrusor muscle, causing contraction during voiding.

whyIncorrect.a: MUSCARINIC (not nicotinic) receptors mediate parasympathetic effects on detrusor. Nicotinic receptors are in autonomic ganglia, not on bladder muscle.
whyIncorrect.d: Alpha-1 receptors are on internal urethral SPHINCTER (contraction), not detrusor. Detrusor has beta-2 (relaxation).

explanations.summary: Bladder emptying: Detrusor muscle CONTRACTION (parasympathetic) is the primary mechanism. NOT water reabsorption, NOT Bayliss effect, and healthy adults have COMPLETE emptying (no residual).

whyCorrect.b: Detrusor muscle CONTRACTION is the key mechanism for bladder emptying. Parasympathetic activation (S2-S4) releases ACh, activating M3 receptors, causing coordinated detrusor contraction.

whyIncorrect.a: No water reabsorption through urothelium. Bladder is impermeable storage organ.
whyIncorrect.c: Bayliss effect is a vascular smooth muscle phenomenon (myogenic autoregulation), not applicable to bladder.
whyIncorrect.d: Healthy adults have COMPLETE bladder emptying with minimal residual (<50 mL). Significant residual indicates pathology.

explanations.summary: During urination: (1) Internal sphincter relaxes due to DECREASED SYMPATHETIC tone (alpha-1 withdrawal); (2) External sphincter VOLUNTARILY relaxes (somatic control). Internal sphincter is NOT voluntary.

whyCorrect.b: Internal urethral sphincter relaxes due to DECREASED sympathetic tone (withdrawal of alpha-1 stimulation). This is autonomic, not voluntary.
whyCorrect.c: External urethral sphincter relaxes VOLUNTARILY via somatic control (pudendal nerve, S2-S4). This initiates voluntary voiding.

whyIncorrect.a: Internal sphincter relaxation is NOT voluntary - it's autonomic (sympathetic withdrawal). Only external sphincter is under voluntary control.
whyIncorrect.d: External sphincter is under SOMATIC (not parasympathetic) control via pudendal nerve. Parasympathetic controls detrusor, not external sphincter.

explanations.summary: Parasympathetic innervation to bladder detrusor originates from SACRAL spinal cord (S2-S4) - the pelvic splanchnic nerves. NOT lumbar, NOT brainstem.

whyCorrect.d: Parasympathetic preganglionic neurons controlling detrusor are in SACRAL spinal cord segments S2-S4. They travel via pelvic splanchnic nerves (nervi erigentes).

whyIncorrect.a: Hypothalamus provides higher control/coordination but doesn't contain preganglionic cell bodies.
whyIncorrect.b: Medulla oblongata contains pontine micturition center but not preganglionic neurons to bladder.
whyIncorrect.c: LUMBAR cord contains SYMPATHETIC neurons to bladder (L1-L2), not parasympathetic.

explanations.summary: Micturition reflex REQUIRES intact SACRAL spinal cord (S2-S4) - this is where parasympathetic preganglionic neurons and the reflex arc are located. Damage here eliminates the reflex completely.

whyCorrect.d: Sacral spinal cord (S2-S4) damage eliminates micturition reflex because: (1) Parasympathetic preganglionic neurons are located here; (2) The basic reflex arc is in sacral segments; (3) Without this, no detrusor contraction can occur.

whyIncorrect.a: Midbrain damage affects coordination but basic spinal reflex can still occur.
whyIncorrect.b: Thoracic cord damage doesn't directly affect sacral micturition center.
whyIncorrect.c: Pons (micturition center) damage impairs coordination but spinal reflex persists (though dyssynergic).
whyIncorrect.e: Lumbar cord contains sympathetic neurons; damage affects storage but reflex can still occur.
whyIncorrect.f: Cortical damage removes voluntary control but reflex persists (can cause incontinence).
whyIncorrect.g: Hypothalamus damage affects higher control but doesn't eliminate basic reflex.

explanations.summary: Parasympathetic preganglionic cell bodies for bladder detrusor are in SACRAL spinal cord (S2-S4). Pelvic splanchnic nerves carry these fibers to bladder.

whyCorrect.b: SACRAL spinal cord (S2-S4) contains parasympathetic preganglionic neurons for bladder. These form pelvic splanchnic nerves that innervate detrusor muscle.

whyIncorrect.a: Lumbar cord (L1-L2) contains SYMPATHETIC preganglionic neurons for bladder, not parasympathetic.
whyIncorrect.c: Medulla oblongata is in brainstem - parasympathetic to bladder is sacral, not cranial.
whyIncorrect.d: Hypothalamus coordinates micturition but preganglionic neurons are in sacral cord.
